markups: Games that allow players to upgrade their equipment sometimes do this by having specific slots for these upgrades. The slots are called <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> after one of the most common appearance of this - that the items have slots into which gems can be fitted to provide various bonuses.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> all have equipment that players can put different types of gems into them while the the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> provides the same functionality through runes. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> has several types of <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style>, including those for cogs rather than gems, limiting which upgrades can be put in which equipment.

<style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> are locations for placing <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> and this dictates the main design options available when introducing them into a game design. Primary is to decide how many <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> the various types of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> should have, and if there are different types of <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> into which only certain types of <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> can be placed.

<style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> are limited in number for any <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> and this makes them into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>. However, this can be changed in some way. Increases in the number of <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> can be the effect of <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> - for example providing the <style="Link"><link="companions">Companion</link></style> Isabela in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> with a "Supportive Corselet" or "Boiled Leather Plates" gives an extra rune slot each to her. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>, blacksmiths can add a gem socket to a bracer or glove at the cost of making them have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enforced%20Ownership">Enforced Ownership</link></style> if equipped (they can make a "Eternal Belt Buckle" which works as an <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrade</link></style> to belts with the same cost attached).

An option existing specifically for <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> is if the <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> placed within them can be remove later. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> hinders this (but not <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age">Dragon Age</link></style>) making the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style> in these games into <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>; while other types of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style> may be irreversible because the <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> are consumed in these case the <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> remains to remind players of their choice. An additional option exists when <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> are permanently locked in <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> - that new <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> may be placed in them but that the old ones are destroyed then.

The management of <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> may be part of the interfaces for <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style> or have their own <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> as for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> provides.

<style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style> gives players the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to choose when to engage in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style> through using <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> on <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>.

When <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> can be removed from <style="CurrentLink">Sockets</style>, players can make <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> between their different benefits that different <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style> can provide. When they cannot be removed, players need to do <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> choices if they should place a particular <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrade</link></style> in a particular <style="CurrentLink">Socket</style> or if they should hope for a better combination later.
